thread.title: Bristol University PhD student accidentally makes explosive chemical used in terror attacks
thread.title_full: Bristol University PhD student accidentally makes explosive chemical used in terror attacks

author: Telegraph Reporters
title: Bristol University PhD student accidentally makes explosive chemical used in terror attacks
text:
Bristol University PhD student accidentally makes explosive chemical used in terror attacks Bristol University was evacuated after triacetone triperoxide - better known as TATP - was 'unintentionally formed' Credit: Olaf Protze/Getty 16 February 2017 • 12:08pm 
A PhD student accidentally created an explosive chemical used in terror attacks, an investigation has found. 
Bristol University confirmed the chemical triacetone triperoxide - better known as TATP - was "unintentionally formed" on Friday, February 3. 
The post-graduate student created the highly dangerous substance as a by-product of another experiment, the inquiry discovered. 
It is the same chemical used in the 7/7 London bombings, the 2015 Paris terror attacks and the Brussels bombings last year. 
Hundreds of staff and students at the university's School of Chemistry were evacuated after the chemical was made. Live at the uni of Bristol where a chemical incident has caused a large-scale evacuation pic.twitter.com/6zlEf0XwNY — Tristan Cork BPost (@TristanCorkPost) February 3, 2017 
E mergency services made sure the building was empty before bomb units removed the explosive substance from the lab and blew it up in the nearby Royal Fort Gardens. 
Police confirmed they are not treating the incident as suspicious. 
A Bristol University spokesman said an investigation was carried out after the incident. The Hazard Team boss has arrived & gets directions to chemical incident at Bristol Uni — Tristan Cork BPost (@TristanCorkPost) February 3, 2017 
H e said: "Following a full investigation, we can confirm that the chemical, triacetone triperoxide (TATP), was unintentionally formed during a routine procedure carried out by a PhD student. 
"The student was following a published literature method and the risk of TATP as a potential by-product had been identified during the risk assessment process. 
"We have robust contingency plans in place to deal with incidents of this nature." Royal Logistics Corps Bomb Disposal have arrived at uni of Bristol chemical incident — Tristan Cork BPost (@TristanCorkPost) February 3, 2017 
T he spokesman added: "As soon as the presence of TATP was identified the student immediately notified those responsible for laboratory safety in the school. 
"A series of actions were then taken which resulted in the precautionary evacuation of the chemistry building and surrounding buildings and the controlled disposal of the substance by the emergency services. No one was injured." 
The chemistry department's risk assessment process is now being reviewed to see if additional checks can be made when similar work is planned in future, the spokesman added. Follow Telegraph News
